awd_titl_txt: Bacterial Reaction Centers With New Photochemical Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
Deciphering the mechanisms by which the movement of protons is linked to electron transfer is an important challenge in understanding biochemical catalysis. Professors James Allen and JoAnn Williams of Arizona State University are directing their efforts to elucidate this linkage for chemical reactions that occur in photosynthesis, nature's fundamental process for converting light into chemical energy. Because control of coupling between proton and electron transfer is critical for achieving efficient energy conversion and chemical transformations, this project aims to generate a more complete understanding of the physical principles that govern these processes in complex systems. The activities offer societal benefits through broadening participation in science and engagement of the wider community. To overcome traditional low graduation rates and limited participation in science degree programs, this project provides students from a local community college with a personal research experience in a supportive environment that encourages their continuation in science. In another avenue of engagement, students work with artists to express the scientific concepts behind research in bioenergy and photosynthesis and present their integration of science and art to the local community.

With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program, with partial co-funding from the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, is supporting Professors James Allen and JoAnn Williams of Arizona State University to help establish molecular concepts that explain how proteins effectively perform proton-coupled, multi-electron-transfer reactions. They are using novel protein design strategies to modify the bacterial reaction center, an integral membrane protein serving as the site of the primary photochemistry in photosynthesis. The yields of proton and electron transfer are being measured for different cofactors and protein environments. The experimental methods combine structure-based protein design, enabled by molecular biology and biochemical techniques, with analysis of the properties of the resulting complexes by optical and magnetic resonance spectroscopy. The project is designed to expand the tools available for designing proton-coupled, electron-transfer reactions for catalysis in biological systems and establish a framework applicable for understanding the progression of oxidation states in the fundamental water oxidation reactions of photosystem II.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A sustainable society requires sources of renewable energy that are efficient, cost-effective, and robust. The achievement of such energy sources represents a significant challenge that requires the development of novel technologies, including the creation of materials that control physical and chemical transformations at a molecular level. Photosynthesis is an ideal platform for such investigations as it performs solar energy conversion using Earth-abundant metals that operate under ambient conditions. In this project, the fundamental biological processes of photosynthesis were examined for their ability to convert light energy into chemical energy by determination of the dependence of the rates and efficiencies of these processes on the controlled transfer of protons and electrons in protein complexes. The focus was on the primary energy transduction event that is the light-induced generation of a charge- separated state in a pigment-protein complex termed the reaction center. The objectives were centered on the use of the reaction center from Rhodobacter sphaeroides as a model system to incorporate specific modifications of functional features such as the redox potential of the primary electron donor. One objective was a systematic analysis of the contributions of specific amino acid residues to light-induced proton release. The results showed a correlation between the proton release from key residues and electron transfer. Another objective was to identify and establish the coupling of the release of protons to electrostatic interactions. The results measured the relationship between proton release and the electronic structures of different donors. Experiments in the third objective established the requirements for the incorporation of redox-active porphyrin molecules that can participate in light-driven electron transfer.

To achieve the goals of this project, reaction centers were produced with cofactor-binding sites and their structural and thermodynamic properties were characterized using various biophysical techniques. Bound synthesized porphyrins were found to be capable of participating in electron transfer reactions involving the cofactors the reaction center in light-dependent processes by measurements using steady-state and time resolved optical spectroscopy. In order to better understand how protons are coupled to electron transfer in reaction centers, a series of mutants with altered protonatable amino acid residues were purified and were characterized in terms of their response to light-induced electron transfer. The results identified a set of residues that were critical for electron transfer reactions involving the bacteriochlorophyll dimer and suggested a new set of amino acid residues that could be involved. Another direction of our work was to investigate how the proton transfer is coupled with high-oxidation and multi-electron reactions. We designed sites on the bacterial reaction centers to be capable binding metal cofactors. Using steady-state and transient optical spectroscopy, we measured the alteration of the functional properties in response to the addition of the cofactors, in particular Mn-porphyrins. These outcomes were distributed to the general scientific audience by presentations at meetings and scientific publications. 

The activities offered societal benefits through broadening participation in science and engagement of the wider community. Several students from community colleges, who otherwise would not have a research experience, were provided the opportunity to perform research on this project and to be mentored concerning their professional development. More broadly, our research and educational activities promoted progress in science by providing enhanced opportunities for undergraduates to gain the experience of undergraduate research through the introduction of a CURE, a Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience. The CURE was designed to provide research experiences for students who have limited opportunities for traditional research, in particular underrepresented students. With the Arizona State University leadership, we redesigned the biochemistry laboratory course for majors and coordinated the upgrade of instrumentation in the undergraduate biochemistry laboratories. The CURE with the updated equipment and laboratory experiments has proven to be sustainable and has been incorporated into the institutional resources as an ongoing course for undergraduate students.
